abstract: pmc Discov Oncol Discov Oncol 4139 discon Discover Oncology 2730-6011 Springer PMC12480339 PMC12480339.1 12480339 12480339 41020917 10.1007/s12672-025-03590-0 3590 1 Analysis Exploring the genetic determinants of the oral microbiome’s role in gastrointestinal cancer risk: Mendelian randomization and genetic correlation analysis in an East Asian population Jin Wei 1 Zhang ZongYao 2 Zhang Hang 3 Jin Xiaoli 3 Wang Jun wangjunoscar@zju.edu.cn 3 1 https://ror.org/059cjpv64 grid.412465.0 Nursing Department, The Second Affiliated Hospital, Zhejiang University School of Medicine, 2 https://ror.org/00q9atg80 grid.440648.a 0000 0001 0477 188X Department of General Surgery, The First Affiliated Hospital of Anhui University of Science and Technology, 3 https://ror.org/059cjpv64 grid.412465.0 Department of Gastroenterology Surgery, The Second Affiliated Hospital, Zhejiang University School of Medicine, 29 9 2025 12 2025 16 478248 1748 23 12 2024 3 9 2025 29 09 2025 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Background The human oral microbiome plays a significant role in systemic health, including potential links to digestive tract cancers. However, few studies have examined the causal relationship between the oral microbiota and digestive tract cancers using robust methodologies. This study aimed to investigate the causal associations between specific oral microbiota and the risk of gastric, esophageal, colorectal, liver, and pancreatic cancers using a Mendelian randomization (MR) approach. Methods We employed a two-sample MR analysis using genome-wide association study (GWAS) data from 2,948 individuals from the CNGBdb for the oral microbiome and over 150,000 individuals from BioBank Japan for digestive cancers. Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with the oral microbiota were selected as instrumental variables, and the inverse-variance weighted (IVW) method was used for causal estimates. Sensitivity analyses, including MR‒Egger regression and leave-one-out tests, were performed to assess pleiotropy and robustness. Linkage disequilibrium score regression (LDSC) was applied to explore genetic correlations. Results Our MR analysis revealed several suggestive associations between the oral microbiota and digestive tract cancers. For esophageal cancer, both Fusobacterium periodonticum P Fusobacterium massiliense P Streptococcus P TM7x P Veillonella rogosae P Haemophilus_D P Campylobacter_A_concisus_D_mgs_2798 P Campylobacter_A_concisus_F_mgs_1384 P Stomatobaculum P Leptotrichia P Mogibacterium P Pauljensenia P Conclusion This study provides novel insights into the causal role of specific oral bacteria in the development of digestive tract cancers. These findings highlight potential microbial targets for cancer prevention and intervention strategies. Keywords Oral microbiome Gastrointestinal cancer Mendelian randomization Causality Genetic correlation https://doi.org/10.13039/501100001809 National Natural Science Foundation of China 82203452 Wang Jun pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © Springer Science+Business Media LLC, part of Springer Nature 2025 Introduction The human oral microbiome is a complex and diverse community of microorganisms, with more than 700 bacterial organisms [ 1 2 3 4 5 6 The impact of the oral microbiome extends beyond the oral cavity, influencing systemic health [ 7 Porphyromonas gingivalis Fusobacterium nucleatum 3 8 9 10 11 Digestive tract cancers, including gastric, esophageal, colorectal, liver, and pancreatic cancers, represent a significant global health burden [ 12 12 13 14 Fusobacterium nucleatum F. nucleatum 15 Porphyromonas gingivalis 16 Mendelian randomization (MR) has gained prominence in epidemiological research as a method to infer causality by using genetic variants as instrumental variables, effectively addressing issues of confounding and reverse causation that are common in observational studies [ 17 18 19 20 21 22 23 The primary objective of this study was to investigate the causal relationships between specific components of the oral microbiome and the risk of developing various digestive tract cancers, including gastric, esophageal, colorectal, liver, and pancreatic cancers, using a MR approach. This investigation will also consider potential pathways through which these bacteria may influence carcinogenesis, providing insights into microbial targets for cancer prevention and therapeutic interventions. Methods Study design This study employs a two-sample MR approach to investigate the causal relationships between the oral microbiome and digestive system cancers (Fig. 1 24  Fig. 1 The workflow of this MR study Data sources For this MR study, we utilized publicly available genome-wide association study (GWAS) data from multiple large-scale consortia. Oral microbiome data were sourced from the CNGBdb, which comprises genetic data from 2,948 individuals from Shenzhen who provided blood samples [ 25 https://db.cngb.org/search/project/CNP0001664/ For digestive system cancers, we utilized GWAS summary statistics from the Japanese Genotype-Phenotype Archive (JGA) under accession numbers JGAS000114/JGAD000123 and JGAS000114/JGAD000220 [ 26 n 1  Table 1 The comprehensive details regarding the phenotypic characteristics and genotypic data Exposures/Outcomes Consortium Ethnicity Sample sizes Case Controls Year Oral microbiome CNGBdb East Asian Tongue = 2017 / / 2021 Saliva = 1915 / / Esophageal cancer Japanese Genotype-phenotype Archive East Asian 160,589 1388 159,201 2021 Gastric cancer Japanese Genotype-phenotype Archive East Asian 167,122 7921 159,201 2021 Colorectal cancer Japanese Genotype-phenotype Archive East Asian 167,691 8305 159,386 2021 Hepatic cancer Japanese Genotype-phenotype Archive East Asian 161,323 2122 159,201 2021 Pancreatic cancer Japanese Genotype-phenotype Archive East Asian 159,700 499 159,201 2021 Selection of instrumental variables (IVs) Single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) significantly associated with the oral microbiome at a genome-wide significance threshold ( P 27 28 29 30 P Mendelian randomization analysis The primary analysis used the inverse-variance weighted (IVW) method [ 31 32 33 34 35 31 https://shiny.cnsgenomics.com/mRnd/ 36 Linkage disequilibrium score regression (LDSC) LDSC was used to assess the genetic correlation between the oral microbiome and digestive system cancers [ 37 Statistical analysis All statistical analyses were conducted using the R software environment (version 4.2.1). MR analyses were performed via the TwoSampleMR Mendelian randomization https://github.com/bulik/ldsc P Results Causal effect of the oral Microbiome on esophageal cancer risk Our MR analysis revealed a significant causal relationship between specific oral microbial taxa and the risk of esophageal cancer. A total of 138 types of oral bacterial species, including 71 tongue and 67 saliva bacterial species, had statistically suggestive relationships with esophageal cancer (IVW_P < 0.05, Fig. 2 Fusobacterium periodonticum Fusobacterium massiliense P P Streptococcus Streptococcus P TM7x P CAG-793 Lancefieldella 2 P  Fig. 2 Causal effect of the oral microbiome on esophageal cancer risk. A B C Discussion This study highlights several suggestive causal associations between specific oral microbiota and digestive tract cancers, including esophageal, gastric, colorectal, hepatic, and pancreatic cancers, using MR analysis. Oral microbiome and Cancers The relationship between the oral microbiome and cancer has been increasingly explored in recent years. Research indicates that disruptions in the balance of oral microbes, known as dysbiosis, may contribute to cancer development both locally (such as in oral cancers) and systemically (affecting distant organs) [ 14 38 Porphyromonas gingivalis Fusobacterium 39 Streptococcus Veillonella 40 Fusobacterium P. gingivalis 41 Interpretation of Our Findings Our findings revealed positive associations between Fusobacterium periodonticum Fusobacterium massiliense Streptococcus TM7x Veillonella rogosae Haemophilus_D Campylobacter_A_concisus Stomatobaculum Fusobacterium Leptotrichia Mogibacterium Pauljensenia Fusobacterium 15 42 Fusobacterium Fusobacterium In gastric cancer, Veillonella rogosae Veillonella 43 Haemophilus_D 44 The protective associations between Campylobacter_A_concisus Stomatobaculum Campylobacter 45 Campylobacter 46 Stomatobaculum longum 47 When multiple MR methods are employed, it is crucial to interpret any inconsistencies in a transparent and scientifically sound manner. In our study, the IVW method served as the primary analytical approach, as it provides the most statistically efficient estimates under the assumption that all IVs are valid. To account for potential violations of this assumption, we complemented the IVW results with several robust MR methods that make different assumptions about the presence and distribution of horizontal pleiotropy, including MR-Egger, weighted median, MR-PRESSO, and ConMix. We emphasized results that were directionally consistent across multiple robust MR methods and cautiously interpreted findings when notable discrepancies or indications of pleiotropy were observed. LDSC LDSC is a method primarily used to estimate the heritability of a trait and to partition heritability across different genomic annotations. It leverages the concept of linkage disequilibrium (LD), which refers to the nonrandom association of alleles at different loci [ 37 Strengths and limitations The strengths of this study lie in its use of a robust two-sample MR approach, which minimizes confounding and reverse causation. The application of sensitivity analyses further supports the validity of our findings by excluding pleiotropy and heterogeneity. Moreover, the inclusion of a large sample size from BioBank Japan and CNGBdb enhances the generalizability of the results, particularly in East Asian populations. However, there are several limitations to consider. First, although MR analysis allows for causal inference, the selected SNPs may not fully capture the complex interactions within the oral microbiome. Second, the lack of significant genetic correlations in LDSC for some cancer types suggests that the role of the oral microbiome in these cancers may be influenced more by environmental or nongenetic factors. Additionally, our study was limited to East Asian populations, and further studies in other populations are needed to assess the generalizability of our findings. Finally, as with all MR studies, residual pleiotropy cannot be completely excluded, although we employed several methods to minimize this risk. Future directions Here, the genetic databases are typically skewed toward European and East Asian Populations. The reasons behind the dominance of above databases may due to historical, resource availability, ethical considerations. We also acknowledge the limited representation of other populations, such as African, South Asian, and Indigenous groups, which may lead to reduced generalizability of findings. To address this disparity, we suggest that future studies should prioritize expanding biobanks with diverse ancestries, encourage international collaborations, and utilize statistical methods such as trans-ethnic meta-analysis to improve the robustness and applicability of genetic findings across different populations. Future research also should focus on further elucidating the mechanisms through which the oral microbiota influences cancer risk, particularly the role of microbial metabolites and host immune interactions. Longitudinal studies integrating multiomics approaches, including metagenomics, metabolomics, and proteomics, could provide deeper insights into the functional roles of these bacteria in carcinogenesis. Conclusion In conclusion, our study provides compelling evidence for the causal role of specific oral bacteria in the development of digestive tract cancers. These findings underscore the potential of the oral microbiome as a target for cancer prevention and therapeutic intervention strategies. Further research is needed to explore these relationships in greater detail and to identify potential avenues for clinical application.
